div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established 1850
Editor & Manager: R SNELLINO.
Prloe; One Plastro Tariff.
TUe8DAY, OCTOBER 17. 1905.
EGYPT AND THE AMERICAN
INSURANCE SCANDALS.

The increase of life insurance brainess in Egypt is one of the many signs of the growth in the intelligence and prosperity of the, peo- ple. Not only are the leading insurance com- panies securely established here, but Canadian, Australian, and American insurance enter- prises have lately turned their attention to this country, and we hare every reason to believe that their efforts in looking so far afield have been crowned with success. There is no system of Government supervision of insurance companies in Egypt, and it is, therefore, of great importance to local policy- holders that they should have some assu- rances as to the integrity of the financiers to whom they have entrusted their hard- earned savings. It is true that Govern- mental supervision in England is very slight, the only thing of this and being the filing of statement* by the companies with the Board of Trade. But the Egyptian policy- holder need have no fear as to the sound- ness of the system on which English in. suranoe business is carried on. The foresight and scrupulousness with which these compa- nies are managed have scoured for them a world-wide reputation for soundness and so- lidity in every branch of their business. But we regret to say that some of the Amer- ican companies, whioh are represented in Egypt, are directed by men who are lacking in the high dense of honor required as es- sential to the success of this class of busi- ness, and who have so sinned against the true oode of business morality that it may eventually be found necessary to prosecute some of them criminally.

Mr. Jerome, the District Attorney-General of New York, recently announced his intention of presenting to an extraordinary grand jury the recent revelations before the committee in regard to the conduct' of life insurance busi- ness. He stated that the inquiry in regard to the Mutual had shown even greater moral obliquity and obuseness on the part of persons holding important positions in the business world than the shocking revelations respecting the Equitable Company. Besides the Mutual Company above referred to, the Equitable and the New York have been doing a considerable business in Egypt, and have a number of Egyptian policy-holders on their lists. It is most necessary, therefore, that the public should be made aware of the extraordinary revelations which are now being made among to the investigations into what are known as the American insurance scandals. In another column we give a succinct account of the actual state of affairs, and when our readers have gone through the story of the scandals they will be of President Roosevelt's opinion, who characterized them as '‘terrible," and who poblicly accused the directors of bringing about a "deplorable scandal” which has not only shaken the confidence "of hundreds of thousands of poor people all over the coun- try... in the provision which they made for their families and for their old age ; but also, by causing want of confidence has affected the whole insurance business of the country and weakened that great tecdency for the promotion of thrift and confidence."

div.head: FRANCE AND ENGLAND.
ENGLAND PREPARED TO FIGHT.
NOTIFICATION TO GERMANY
div.p: Paris, October 16.

The "Echo De Paris" learns from Berlin from a semi-official source that Lord Lansdowne informed Germany in June, that though no Anglo-French alliance had been concluded or promised, yet Great Britain would take part with France, if war should break out through Germany's fault (Reuter)
Cologne October 16.
The "Koelnische Zeitung" says that Ger- many asked no explanation either of France or England regarding tho recent revelations (H.)
THE "ENTENTE MUNICIPALE."
FRENCH COUNCILLORS GO TO LONDON
Paris, October 16.
60 members oF the Municipality have start- ed for their visit to London, there there will be all sorts of festivities. They will be received by the King to-morrow. (Reuter)
Paris, October 16.
Sixty Municipal councillors have left on a visit to London.(Havas)

div.head: THE PROPITIATION OF,FINLAND.
RUSSIAN TROOPS REPATRIATED.'
div.p: St. Petersburg, October 16.
The Russian troops in Finland are being sent back to Russia. This is considered as indicating a reversion to the policy of the propitiation of Finland. (Reuter)

div.head: SITUATION IN THE CAUCASUS
MOBILISATION OF RESERVES.
div.p: St. Petersburg, October 16.
The reserves throughout the Caucasus are being mobilised owing to the continued cri- tical situation. (Reuter)

div.head: EVACUATION OF MANCHURIA.
COMPLETED IN SIX MONTHS.
div.p: Tokio. October 16.
Japan is preparing to begin the evacuation of Manchuria at once It is expected that it will be completed in six months. (Reuter)

div.head: HARON KOMURA'S HOMECOMING
MIKADO'S MARKS OF FAVOR.
div.p: Tokio, October 16.
Baron Komura has returned and has been received with special marks of favor by the Emperor, who expressed his pleasure at the conclusion of a satisfactory peace. (Renter)

div.head: MARRIED AND-DISGRACED.
GRAND DUKE CYRILS FATE-
div.p: St. Petersburg, October 16.
The Grand Duke Cyril has been dismissed from the Army, deprived of all honors, and excluded from Russia, for marrying the divorc- ed Grand Duchess of Hesse. (Reuter)

div.p: Tokio, October 16.
Tho Japanese have seized the American steamer Centennial in Soya Strait - (Reuter)

div.p: Paris, October 16.
Tho Prince of Bulgaria has arrived here on an official visit. (Havas)

Suez Canal—155 vessels passed through the Canal from the 6th to the 13th inst., the dues from which amounted to frs. 4,100,485.74.
The Brindisi Mail will be leaving Port Said every Sunday, instead of Monday, for the next six months or so.
A.C.C.—The Squash court will be closed from to-day to allow of painting walls, stretching wire-netting, etc.
Zizinia Theatre — Cavalreto Salvini make his first appearance at the Zizinia this evening in Shakespeare's tragedy Othello.
Stray Dogs.— Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Waijy district of Cairo during tho night of Wednesday will be poisoned by the police.
Hedjaz Railway. — On Sunday last, in honor of the 65th birthday of H.I.M the Sultan, the Deraa-Haifa branch of the above railway was formally opened to traffic.
Khkdivial Reception.— On tho occasion of his departure from. Alexandria for Cairo, his Highness will hold a reception at Rasel Tin Palace on Tuesday, 24th inst., commencing at 9 a.m.

Cairo Scientific Society. — A meeting of tho society will take place at the School of Medicine, Cairo, on Saturday, 21st inst, at 4.15 p.m. Mr. A. Lucas will read a paper on “The Blackened Rocks of the Nile Cataract," and Mr. P. S. Barlow a "Note on tin Construc- tion of Osmotic Cells.”

School of Medicine.—On Sunday the result of the examination of the students of the third and fourth years was made public. Sixteen competitors obtained their diploma, and twenty students of the third year were entitled to enter upon the fourth years come.

Fire at Menshieh. Fire broke out at about 11 p.m. yesterday in the shop of an Italian grocer in the Menshieh. Tho Fire Brigade arrived promptly with the engine and pumps, and after an hour's labour the tire was extinguished. The damage has not yet been estimated.

San Stefano Casino. ,-The Bracsle orehos- tra will continue giving the usual concerts until Sunday next, the 22nd inst. We are informed that on Saturday next, at 9.30 p.m., the celebrated telepathic "phenomenon,"Count E. Bellini, will give a final seance of auto- suggestion, which promises to be very interest- ing. Admission will be P.T.5, and for this occasion the season tickets will be suspended.

Emigration .from Syria —Owing to scarcity of work in Syria, the natives of the country are emigrating in large numbers. Last week, abou 1,000 emigrants embarked on the Mea- sageries steamer for America. Three of these, on their arrival at Alexandria, had a dispute, in the coarse of which one of them, named Abdallah, was seriously injured and had to be taken to hospital. The other two were arrested.

Transports. -There are now three trans- ports in the Canal—the Plassy and Africa, outward bound, and the Assaye, homeward Details for embarkation in the transport Aessye to-day left Cairo by the 6.15 p.m. train yes- terday. Those from Alexandria left by the 3.40 p.m. train yesterday, changing at Benba and joining the train which leaves that station at 7.1 p.m

Field Firino in Cairo. — The British Mounted Infantry will carry out field firing daily (Sunday, 22nd inst, excepted), from Monday, 16th, to Tuesday, 24th inst., in Cairo, commencing each day at.S.SO a.m., and ter- minating at 8.30 a.m., except on Tuesday, 24th inst., when the hours will be from 5.30 a.m. to 12 noon. The Commandant, Abbassieh. has made the necessary arrangements for the safety of the troops and public.

Fatal Fire in Cairo.—The Cairo City Fire Brigade were called out at half past eleven yesterday morning to an outbreak of fire which occurred in a big laundry in the Mamnvheh district. When they arrived on the scene it appeared as if the outbreak were serious, but happily it was extinguished in a short time, and before very much material damage was done, though one room was destroyed and some machinery was badly damaged. Unfortun- ately a native man was burnt to death. The cause of the fire is not known, but it is supposed to have originated in a stock of benzine and petroleum which was kept on the premises. Probably the amount of the damages will not be found to exceed £'0.

div.head: PREMIER NOT TO RESIGN. A BASELESS RUMOUR.
div.p: We aro authorised to state that the reports of the approaching resignation of H.E. Musta- jha Pasha Fehmy from the Prime Ministership, which have appeared in the colomns of one of our contemporaries, are absolutely without frondation.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
HOWARD BEY'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: El MirJai F. J. L Howard Bey Las retired from the Egyptian Army. In expressing his regret at the retirement of E! Miralai Howard Bey from his Highness the Khedive's Army, the Sirdar, in an Army Order, places on record his appreciation of tho services rendered by this officer during the last ten years. Daring this period El Miralai Howard Bey has taken part in the following campaigns and actions Expedition to Dongola, 1896 ; Ni'e Expedition, 1897 ; Nile Expedition, 1898.—Battle of "Khartoum Nile Expedi- tion, 1899.—Final defeat of the Khalifa. He has held the appointments of Staff Officer lor Supplies, and Governor and Commandant, Suakia Province and District, in which the excellence of his work has' been very con- spicuous. The Sirdar, on behalf of-the Egyp- tian Army, wishes El Miralai Howard Bey every success in his future career. Leave of absence, on private affairs, has been granted to El Bimbashi Moore, Junior Inspector, Kasala Province, and El Bimba- ahi Ferrar, 15th Sudanese.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: Sir Malcolm Mcllwraith was received in private audience by the,Khedive yesterday at Ras el-Tin Palace, The Financial Adviser left to-day On a tour of inspection of some of the provincial tribunals, beginning at Port Said, and will return to Cairo at the end of the week.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT CO.
div.p: The "acte d'association" of the above com- pany was signed yesterday at the mixed Tribunals in Cairo, when a copy,of the statute was deposited at the Greffe. It is non expected that the new company will be floated in the coarse of the next fortnight through the Hb Anglo- Egyptian Bank, but only shall portion of the capital, as we mentioned a few days Back, will be offered to the public, as the rest has already been privately subscribed. It has not yet been decided who will be the third British member of the board, as the gentleman to whom the post was offered, although authorised to accept it by his directors, has not yet done so. The company has rented the offices formerly occupied by the Daira Sanieh Co. in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

Wo have been asked to mention that, in conformity with the Code, the shareholders will be entitled to a dividend of 5 per cent, before any distribution is made to the holders of founders' shares, instead of 4 per cent, as we were informed, and which we stated was tho rate in our previous article.

According to the statutes the company is constituted with the object of acquiring land in Egypt and the Sudan, on purchase or on lease, ameliorating the same, and re-selling or letting it to cultivators in small lots and on the most favorable conditions. The company will likewise undertake irrigation or any other works relating to agriculture in this country or in tho Sadan, as well as making advances to the fellaheen on security of land or crops. In fact it will fulfil all the conditions of an enter- prise which Lord Cromer in his last report has strongly urged upon native capitalists to turn their attention to, and we have no doubt that the Anglo-Egyptian Allotment Company will be hailed by the small cultivators as a benefactor.

Besides the share capital of LE. 500,000, divided into £195,000 shares of LE. 4 each, the board is authorised to raise a like sum on debentures if found necessary, and on condi- tions to be determined later. The company also reserves to itself the right of opening branches or agencies throughout the country whenever it considers this course advissable.

The net profits, after deduction of all ex penses, internet on loans, and remuneration of the board of directors, will be apportioned as follows:—five per cent. to a reserve fond, and five per cent to the shareholders ; of the sur- plus, ten per cent, will be allotted to the directors, and of the remaining balanoe 70 per cent will be paid to the shareholders and 30 per cent to the holders of founders' shares.

The utmost credit is, we are told, due to Yoassef Bey Sadik, formerly judge of the Native Tribunals, in having brought the first venture of this kind to a successful issue. He proceeded to London and Paris at his own expense during the summer, and there com- pleted the arrangements for bringing out the company. In our issue of the 22nd September we gave the names of the five native members of the board, all of whom are well-known through- out the country.

div.head: COMING ROYAL VISIT. PORT SAID ARRANGEMENTS. PRINCE TO VISIT CAIRO.
div.p: The inhabitants of Port Said are already beginning to prepare for the forthcoming visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales, and to all appearances local Britishers are determined to give their Royal Highnesses a fitting wel- come.

The arrangements which have so far been made for the Royal trip are as follows. Their Royal Highnesses will leave London on the 19th inst. and proceed to Ganos, where they will embark on the 21st on H.M.S Renown. This warship will be accompanied by H.M S. Terrible, Suffolk, and Lancashire as far as Port Said, where they are expected to arrive at midday on the 26th inst. All four vessels will be moored in the Dutch Basin, which is being specially reserved for them.

The Royal party will probably proceed to Cairo on the evening of their arrival, or, at the latest, on the following morning, spending a day or two in the Capital. They will afterwards return to Port Said and re-embark on the Renown, which, on resuming her voyage, will be aocompanied by the Terrible—the other two ships remaining here for station orders. In the Red Sea the two ships will probably be met and escorted by a detachment of the East Indian Squadron to Aden before their final departure for India.

div.head: THE REFLOATED DREDGER.
div.p: As reported in yesterday's issue, the large dredger Pharaon, which was sunk some five months ago in the Dutcb Basin, was success- fully refloated on Friday afternoon, after great efforts by M. Dornoy and his staff. Oa being examined it was found that the vessel was absolutely full of mud and sand, besides being covered with seaweed. She will probably be partially sunk again, when the pumps will be used to try and pump the mud and sand out of her. At present she is so heavy with the accumulation of sand and mud that she cannot be lifted sufficiently high to allow of her entering the floating dock.

div.head: MALTA FEVER PREVALENT.
div.p: Malta fever ia very prevalent in Port-Said at present. Several British residents are more or less seriously ill, and there have been a few deaths this week. The doctor at the Govern ment Hospital iv very ill, and has been in a critical condition all the week. This morning however, a slight improvement was reported. Dr. Betts, of Cairo, acts as locum tenens.

div.head: TOR LIGHTHOUSE.
div.p: Tor lighthouse is now in course of construc- tion. One of Bell’s Asia Minor steamers, the Fortuna, has already passed through the Canal with a complete cargo of building material The construction of the lighthouse is in the hands of a French firm, and I understand that the cost of building,exclusive of the cost of the light and lens, is 75,000 frs. There were German competitors tendering, and at a rate which was slightly lower than the accepted oontract The building is to be completed within two years.

div.head: LORD CROMER’S RETURN.
NATIVE PRESS COMMENTS.
div.p: "Al-Express," under the heeding of “Wel- come to the Reformer," makes the following ( remarks on Lord Cromer’s return “The comer is one whom Egyptians love, not as the British Diplomatic Agent working, as he must, for his own Government.... but as a gentleman and a man of honor who has spent two thirds of his life in Egypt Had it not been for his diplomatic office Lord Cromer would have won the right to be elected as its minister by the nation. He has studied the Egyptian character, has associated with the Egyptian people, and in his relations with them has a1 ways proved the benevolent European who likes the peasant aids the weak, and opposes a determined resistance to the oppression which he hates. Lord Cromer's policy has two aims : to extend British influence in Egypt and to increase the wealth, commerce, and culture of Egypt and the freedom of every degree and rank of the people...."

The writer then discusses the appointment of a successor to the late Sheikh Mohammed Abdou, and is certain that the now Grand Mufti will have the support of Lord Cromer, and confidently hopes that he will "confess no influence above that of the law and no judge- ment above that of God."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: On Saturday last, the Junior and Senior Championships were swum off at the Gabbari graving dock before a very numerous attend- ance. The hon. secretary, Mr. H. S. Martin, acted as starter, and sent the Juniors off for their 60 yards swim to a good start, the follow- ing competing: Harry Eisworth, H. Mit- chinson, W. H. Talbot, M. L. Delanoy and C. E. L Randall. A very even race ensued but “little" Elsworth was too ambitious and got ahead by himself and was exhausted before he could be recalled to make a fresh start with the other competitors. Randall soon show- ed his superiority, and swimming well throughout won somewhat easily by about 10 yards, Talbot and Delanoy being second and third respect- ively within a yard of each other. The silver challenge cup for this race was presented by Messrs. Borman and Co. and the three prizes by the club. Master Randall has now won the cup two years in succession, and should he be suc- essful next year the cup becomes his own property.

After this followed the event of the year, viz, the 110 yards seniors championship for a handsome silver challenge cup presented by Mr. H. P. Kingham. There were 9 starters and but for the absence of the E.T.C. staff at Saez there would have been a far larger entry. The following started, viz, Messrs. J. Bros- comb, A. B. Collier, E. A. Darton. A. A. Boole- stone, G. D. Lovell, N. Lupton, W. 0. Mace, W G. B. Webb and W.Wood. The race was well contested, and until the last 80 yards there was no choice between Collier and Ecclestone who were swimming neck and neck, they both took too much notice of each other, and in the meantime Darton, who had been swimming steadily throughout, gradually overtook them and won a sp'oodid race by a yard and a half, and this in spite of the fact that he had recent- ly undergone an operation for a poisoned foot. Last year he was fifth in the same race, and the present result speaks volumes for the progress he has made. Collier was seoond and Boole- stone third, barely a foot dividing the two. After these events a polo match was p'ayed between the dab and a team from H. H. 8. Alla, represente 1 by the following : A.8.C.— Messrs Darton, Ecclestone, Lovell, Lepton, Randall,Webb andWood.H.H.8. Aida—Messrs Ames, Bright, Haroty, Irvin,8auuders,Winter, and Watt. The olnb at once deserted authority, and before thegame was three miriutesold Darton secured the ball from a neat pass by Lovell and placed the ball into the oorner of the net, ! Winter having no chanoe of getting at the ball. After this reverse Lieut. Watt (captain for the . H.H.8. Alia) would have pat his side on equal terms had Webh(who oaptained the dub seven) not oonoeded a oorner throw. Notwithstanding that the members had swam in the previous contests,the faotmadtno difference to their ex- odlent paseingflpeed and all round play, and their superiority was very apparent from the tart,with thewetult that before half-time Wood sonred another goal.

Daring the interval the hon. sec. gave ons of his usual exhibitions to the delight of thorn t present On resuming the match even play was witnessed until doee on time, when three more goals, were soured by the dob through Darton, ' Ecclestone and Wood. We may add that for ' H.M.8. Aida Messrs. Watt Irvin and Winter ^ played exoellently, and but for the grand goal- keeping of the latter the soore mast have been far larger.

After this the prizes (given by the dub) were presented to the suooesaful competitor* by Mr. Wal'er P. Sujeant, (ohairman), who made a short but appropriate speech to each. Thus ended the third aud most snooessfnl season of the A9.C, aid there is no donbt that the dub has been established on a firm footing in Alexandria.
Sir Massie and Lady Blomfidd have offered a prize for next year’s sports, and H.H. Prinoe Ad* Hainan Paths has expressed his desire to ' make his Challenge Cop an annual contribution.

div.head: GYMKHANA AT GHIRGEH.
div.p: It occurred to Mr. Harisborne, tho popular and energetic agent of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt at Ghirgeb, that the time was come when some effort should be made to aireliorate the lot of the unfortunate beasts of burden in the moadirieh. In this idea he is by no means alone, but his sympathy is of that active cha- racter which is not content with theory, but must find vent in practice.' He, therefore, approached the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which welcomed most cordially the effort which he proposed to make. The next step was to interest the community— a matter of some difficulty, the idea being so far without parallel in the district. To do this it was thought that a gathering of the inha- bitants would afford an excellent opportunity to explain the object in view, and that no method of convencing the people would prove so effective as a gymkhana. The result was that on Sunday last 7,000 people assembled on the course at Ghirgeh. These included a large proportion of the notables of the province, headed by the sub-mundir, who, since the very commencement of the movement, has exhibited a close interest and given his hearty support The programme was carefully arranged to provide interest for the varying tastes of the spectators. Perhaps the most popular item on the programme was the handicap for men over 60, which was won by a hale old veteran of 76 summers, who crossed the line' but little in front of a venerable old gentleman whose com- mand of language elicited unstinted praise and some laughter, when, on being awarded the second prize of P.T. 50, he protested that a sovereign would be little recompense enough for his unwanted exertions.

A novel item was the contest between village "champions." Unexpected difficulty was experienced in bringing the competitors to the mark, and it ultimately transpired that a rumour was current that the winners of this event would be required for military service. None the less, representatives of 16 villages started, and after an exciting contest, the village of Owlad Yehia Bahri, represented by Tevrfik, was declared winner; and the omdeh was presented with a silver watch in comme- moration of the event

Among those present in the grandstand we noticed the sub-mondir, Hussein Bey Waasif, Director of Irrigation, Fakry Abdel Noor, German Consular Agent Kamil Eff. Butrus, Salim Butrus, Bishai Malach, George Mishrigi, Labib Abdel Noor, Nimr Abdel Malack, mahoun and mulhir of police, the postmaster, the station-master, Dr. Zaki, Mo- hamed Namani Bey, and very many others. At the close of the proceeedings the sub- moudir presented the prizes and set forth the objects of the gathering in a few well-chosen words which were listened to with the greatast interest.

Any acounnt would be incomplete which did not pay a tribute to the mamonr el markas, for the arrangements made for tho cont ol of the crowd, and the orderliness of the spect- ators, whose nunmbers far exceeded estimates, and consequently reparations, so that some discomfort was unavailable,but was none the less born with imperturbable good humour.
The Sirdar, Mr. Machell Sir M. Mcllwraith, and Sir Elwin Palmer have returned to Cairo.
Mr. Borchgrevink, Procureur General to the Mixed Tribunals, returned by the S.S. Cleo- patry yesterday.
Judge Sanders has also returned from Europe.

Sir John Rogers will arrive at Port Said on the 23rd inst. , Tho death is reported at New York of Mrs Catherine Penfield, wife of Mr. Frederick Courtland Penefield, former American Consul- General in Egypt.
Mr. Harold Harris, F. C. S., left Port Said yesterday for Europe.

Liett. C. G. R. Sydney-Turner, A.S.C., has been granted leave of absence, on private affairs, to January 31, 1906. Sister M. Worthington, Q.A.I.M.N.S., is granted leave of absence, on urgent private affairs, to January 27, 1906.

M. A. de Pauliny and family were amongst the passengers by the S.S. Iraunaddy, which arrived at Port Said on Sunday from Mar- seilles. M. de Pauliny is returning to Cairo to resume his duties as chief engineer of the new works on the Egyptian State Rail ways, after a well-earned rest of tome months, having for years past refused to avail himself of his annual leave in order to devote all his energies to the completion of the new line from ismailia Port Said, in connec- tion with which he received a reocognition of his services in the Farrer Commission's report. Another passenger by the same vessel was Saweeria Eff. Basta, (eldest son of the late Basta Bey, a well-known Copto philanthropist of Sohag.) This gentleman has been staying in England for some months for the benefits of his health, which, we are glad to hear, is now fully restored.

Le tribunal mixte des contravention da Caire a rendu hier un jugement qui est en contra- diction avec un precedent jugement rendu par La juridiction iudigene presque entre les me- mes parties.

Le tribunal indigene de Beni Souet avait con- damne en dernier ressort le tenaucierd un hotel a fermer son establissement parce qu’il l'avait ouvert malgre I’opposition de la moudirieb. Celle oi pretendait que le quartiar ou 1'hOtel est situe n’est pas un quartier ouvert au com- merce mais uniquement destine a 1‘habituation des families.

Lors de l'execution du jugement du tribunal indigene, l’huissier dut se retiror par suite de la presence d’un sujet francis qui se dissait cessionnaire dudit hotel. Le juge des referes, saisi de la question, ordonna la suspension de poursuites ; le parquet mixte dut alors intenter de noavean l’action contre. 1‘opposant francais par devant le tribunal des contraventions. Celui-ci vient d'acqaitter l’inculpe et d'autoriser l'oaverture de l’establishement en se bassant sur ce que l’establisement incrimine a ete ouvert avant le noavesa reglement sur les establisie- ments publics et que le ministre de l’interieur daus la notice explicative du reglement avait bien recommande aux moudirs et gouverneras, de ne pas s'ettaquer aux establissements ante- riearoment exists.

div.head: LA COMMISSION DES LOCATAIRES
div.p: M. le Directeur de ‘Egyptian Gazette.

La lettre dorite par fa Commission des Locataires pour protester contre mon article sur la question des Loyers ou, je la considerais comme disparue est sa premiero manifestation d’existence depuis bientot une annec. Et quelle surprise n’estce pas de voir un comite. si fringant a l’origine, mais ensuite tombe en lethargie complete, se reveiller tout-a-coup pour affirmer qu’il est vivant!

On a vu de la sorte des personnes saisies d’un mal mysterieux assister a tous les prepa- ratifs de leur enterroment, impaissants a pro ferer une parole ou a faire un signe, mais com. prenant tout, enteudant tout, voyaut tout. Une circonstance fortuite, une forte emotion pea- vent les tirer de ce sommeil, plus terrible que la mort
C’est ainci que d’insdrer dans mon article sur la question des Loyers que la Commission dasijooatairoi avait cessd do vivre a suffi pour la ramener a la vie.

Depuis an an silo assistait impassible k l’angmentation des loyera ; les pr.-pridtaires redoublaient loan exigences ot lours vexations sans qaelle on tdmoignllt la moindre surprise ; teat renchdrissait, la vie devenait de plus en plus difficile, et la Commission qai devait renverser la Manioipalitd, iotimiderle Qoaver nement et mater les propridtaires no sonffliit mot

Mais a peine est-il question de sa chute que cette parole ensorcelee la remet debout. El c’est si vrai qu’elle a dormi tout ce temps-la qu'a part la notion de son existence elle ne re souvient de rien et renvoie les questioneurs a ses architectes pour plus armples renseigne- ments.
Ravi d'avoir ressuscite la Commission des Locataires d'une mort apparente qui mettait tout Alexandrie en deuil, agrez, etc. A. G.

div.head: THE ECLIPSE OF THE SUN.
EYE WITNESS'S ACCOUNT.
div.p: The following interesting account of the recent eclipse of the son, which appears in the October number of the All Saints Church Magazine, is from the pen of the Rev. J. F. Burns, assistant chaplain at Cairo As I found that I could leave Cairo on Monday night, see tho eclipse from Assouan and return to Cairo by 7.20 on Sunday morn- ing, it recieved a great pity to miss such a splendid opportunity. Thanks to the kindness of the Rev. D.M. Thornton and the Rev. P. I. Anderson, 1 was able to go with an easy con- science. Tho 8'o’clock train on Monday was quite an “Eclipse special" as most of the pas- sengers were going to Assouan to see it After travelling through clouds of dost we arrived at Luxor at 9.80. We loft again at 10 o’clock and soon felt ourselves bring baked in what seemed to ba really an oven on wheels, and only called by courtesy a saloon. I am told that the journey from Luxor to Assouan at this time of the year is one of the hottest in the world. I quite believe it true. But all journeys, however hot and dusty, come to an end, and ours ended punctually at 4 30; soon we were in the Savoy Hotel enjoying the luxury of a bath in the red muddy water of the Nile. It did not look inviting, but it was most refreshing. We found the various missions in a consider- able state of excitement. They were going through a final rehearsal; in fact a sort of dress rehearsal of the actual work to he done during the eclipse. These went off without a hitch.

The next morning I went to see Philae and the Assouan Dam with two others, re- turning across the desert on donkeys. Near the railway station, in fact almost on the platform, was the big 120 ft reflecting ca- mera, and the ground all round bad just been well flooded by the fire-engine so that no dust might get on to ^e reflectors. One mirror reflects the image of the sun 120 ft along a canvas tube on to another mirror, which in turn reflects it back along the same tube to a camera placed beside the first mirror. At the time of the eclipse, just before totality, the afternoon train was seen approaching, but as this vibration would have ruined all the exposures, that is for as long as the train was moving, it bad to be stopped at all costs. lo this they were successful by dint of much shouting, and the train came to a standstill outside the station. After lunch I made a complete tour of all the stations of observation, The island had been practically converted into a big observatory. There was one direct telescopic camera 40 ft long, built up in a screen, with a detached screen all round this, to prevent the slightest movement being caused by a possible wind; but perhaps the most, attractive camera of all was that which was called the cross-eyed lady. It consisted pf four photographic telescopes nearly parallel, to photograph the Leavens in the immediate vicinity of the sun. On seeing this strange combination of telescopes one immediately ap- predates the happy appellation of 'crosseyed." The eclipse began at 3.26 p.m. Near me was a reporter for an Arabic newspaper, and as soon as be saw that the eclipse and commenced he tamed round and spent some considerable time in prayer. As the eclipse progressed one felt as if we were looking at everything through blue glass ; this naturally became more and more marked as the sun was increasingly j' obscured. But all the same it was very remark- able what a great amount of light even the smallest part of the exposed son gave Whether this is noticeable in other parts of the world I cannot say; it may be due to the clear- ness of the atmosphere at Assouan. At any rate it made the change from sunlight to darkness very marked. This change same suddenly at the last. A great black shadow swept down over the opposite bill, across the reverend the sun was in total eclipse. Then it was that One could look with the naked eye. It would be wrong to say that the ooron biased forth, because it was only a pale white glow on a background of black, but it somehow conveyed the impression of biasing firth. The rays cf light stream'd forth from every part of the ink blaco disc of the moon, and tho longest streamers appeared to come from the son spot' area and to be about two diameters of the son in length at the left band top corner there was a small prominence (actually 600 miles high, I be- lieve) projecting beyond the moon's diso; this glowed in the moat brilliant fashion, the colour being that of biasing amethyst. Totality began at 4.83 min. 6 seconds, and after two minutes two other glowing promin- ences appeared at the bottom right hand 1 corner ; these grew brighter and brighter until they were lost in the brightness of the sun itself as it shone forth again. During the 2 i min. 24 seconds totality one saw the planet Mars and several stars, also a faint afterglow on the north and south horison, though, of course, the corona was what chiefly held one’s attention. There was a strange stillness broken only by the sound of distant tom-toms and shooting, from Assouan across the Nile. There was practically no wind, and the temperature only fell from 107° at three o’clock to 97° at 5 o’clook.

The natives believed that a serpent was rating up the sun and heat their tom-toms and shouted in order to frighten it away. They also believed that all the scientific instrumints were brought up to Assouan for the same purpose, bat whether the serpent Was frightened off by their tom toms or our increments, is for tom to decide, And I have but little doubt bot that they have already done so, and in favor of their drama Pot have they not succeeded in rimes past alt by themselves without the help of any scientific instrument 7 They were greatly impressed by our fore-knowledge of the approach and time of the eclipse, and this knowledge to an intimacy with inn and Afreets. At dimmer we heard that the eclipse was a complete success, and tour small amount of credit to ourselves in consequence; for from some cause or another we 'll seems to feel that if had not been there the eclipse Of 1905 would not have proved the success Which It undoubtedly was.

div.head: THE AMERICAN INSURANCE SCANDALS.
div.p: The revelation now being made as to the manner in which the affairs of the great American insurance companies, the Equtiable tho New York Life, and the Mutual are con- duc’ed have astounded the financial world. The trouble began with the Equitable, and its original causes are obscure. The Equitable had in 1904 £84,000,000 of assets and a steadily growing surplos of profi's over and above the liabilities to policy-holders. Until the winter of 1904 it bad the reputation of the Bank of England. It was controlled mainly by two men, its vice-president Mr. Hyde, and its president, Mr. Alexander. Mr. Alexander was the trustee under the will of Mr. Hyde, senior, father of tho vice-president and founder of the company, and was a man of years and high standing in the Now York business world. Mr. Hyde was a young man, 29 years of age, and more notorious than respected. Pro- minent in New York society for his immense and prodigal expenditure, and for. his insanely costly and altogether ridiculous entertain- ments, he seems to have been regarded as a man of pleasure pure and simple, and the suspicion which his follies aroused led one or more of his fellow directors on tho board of the company to devise schemes for eliminating him from its control.
THE POWERS BEHIND.

The leader in this movement was Mr. Alexander, bot it most not be supposed that , his motives were entirely disinterested, since he has since not scrupled to join hands with the very man whom he attacked. The war between Mr. Hyde and Mr. Alexander opened with an attempt on the part of the latter to give the policy-holders the right to choose the officials who were to manage their property and savings. The con- cern was to be made a mutual one, in the true sense. In November last it became known that Mr. Alexander sought to past Mr. Hyde from the porition of first vice-president of the company, and presently a statement emanating from Mr. Alexander was published, to the effect that Mr. Hyde’s re-election "would be most prejudicial to the welfare and progress of the society. . . . Mr. Hyde's prominence in various ways .and his acts as vice-president are 'such as tend to provoke critisim of the society, to create misgivings as to the con- servatism of its management, and to injure its business as an institution which has been uniformely held oat to tbs publis as conducted solely on the mutual plan.
WHEN THIEVES FALL OUT

As soon as this information reached the New York Press cynics remarked that "when thieves fall out, honest men come by their own,” and the criticism seems to have alarmed a the combatants. For alter a fierce fight in the board-room a truce was patched up in February. Mr. Hyde was reelected vice president; Mr. Alexander remained president, and his scheme of mutualizing the company was approved.

But in the course of tho fight the public had been permitted to learn that a you off man of a 29, of no visible business capacity, controlled nearly £100,000,000 of capital, that he had made numerous unwise investments with that a capital ; that be bad bean involved in the dis- mat fiasco of the United States Shipbuilding Company ; and that he was generally an “un safe” man.

A conference of Equitable agents called for Mr. Hyde's retirement from the company, and when the two parties to the dispute, renewing their previous quarrel, admitted that the offi cials and directors of the company, including both the immoral Mr. Hyde and the virtuous Mr. Alexander, bad farm ad syndicates for speculative purposes, and in them employed the fonds of tho society to obtain profit for themselves, the American public demanded someone’s blood.

So monumental a scandal required dose at thorough investigation. The wildest reports as to the condition of the company were our rent It was said that it was insolvent though tho allegation was absurd, and there was no heinous crime which was not imputed to its officials. It was quite clear from what the two factions had published about each other that the law of the United States, which forbids any director or insurance official to make per- sonal profit by making sales to his society or loans of its funds, had been continually violat- ed, and to meet the criticism of the Press and policy holders the conduct of the Equitable’s affairs wav investigated by a committee of directors, one of whom was Mr. Friok. The Frick committee. on which figured Mr. Harriman, the famous railway magnate, pre- sented a scratching report to the Equituble board, whereupon Mr Hyde and Mr. Alexander join- ed hands, forced Mr. Friok and Mr. Harriman n off the board, and rejected the report, which Mr. Prick forthwith gave to the American Press.
WHOLESALE INDICTMENT.

Its, disclosures were of the gravest nature. It was shown that Mr. Alexander, with Mr. Hyde a and certain other persons, had sold bonds to the amount of £2,600.000, indirectly, to the company. Mr. Hyde, the report stated, “habi- tually involved the soceiety In transactions of great magnitude without the previously ob- tained sanction of the executive committee. He carried large amounts of stock belonging a to the society in his own name without having first secured the authority of the society ; he used the funds ot the society to pay for the “Cambon" dinner (one of his entatious and extravagant entertainments given to the French Ambassador in the United States), which be subsequently returned; he conducted and participated in the profits of the syndicates described in his letter of April 27, having frequently as a number of the executive com- mittee voted for the purchase of such securi- ties . . . and be has boon guilty of other irregular acts. . . treating the society and Its affairs largely as if they were his own Personal conoern.”

The officials of the company were no better than their muter. "Ai to the other officers of the society, the committee found that a general looseness has prevailed in the administration of the society affairs . . . and that there is a general lacking in the organisation, of that Strong moral fibre so essential for the accom- lishment of satisfactory results."

Other and not les serious charges were that the minutes had not been properly kept, that the director* had failed to do their duty, and had exercised purely nominal control over the company, and that their title to office ni in Many cases open to question, since the stock needed to qualify them wu transferred to them from Mr. Hyde by what wu practioclly a nominal sale.

There farther disclosures naturally increased the anxiety and indignation of the stockholders who had been plundered by Mr. Hyde, Mr. Alexander, and the host of honored and re- spected names figuring among the directors and Officials of the Equitable, and the demand was formulated that the oulprits should be made to discharge their ill-gotten gains. Thirty Phila- delphian policy holders, representing policies of over £1,000.000, brought an action to secure the appointment of a receiver, on the ground that the Equitable Company wu insolvent, charging the management with “waste, mis- appropriation of fonda and fraud," and requir- ing the return of the plunder made by what Americans describe u “graft and grab.” That action is still proceeding, and meantime the following charges have been made and for the cost part established by the Prick report and by the report of Mr. Hendricks, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York :—
PARADISE FOR LADY TYPISTS.

That Mr. Hyde at the age of twenty-four FIXED hie own salary at £6,000, and speedily raised it -to £90,000 ; that not oontent with his £90,COO he took another £4,500 from the subsidary companies controlled by the Equita- ble ; £3. 2O for salaries paid the Equitable to his personal servants - of which £2,400 or a lady typist ; £2,400 for travelling and Sundry expenses, for which. he rendered no account; and large earns u dividends on his holding of the stock of companies to which he had granted extraordinarily favorable leases Equitable property or buildings. That "he Exacted salary out of all proportion to his age, ability or raise of hie service, and caused Those of his immediate friends or favorites to Be unduly advanced. He is mainly responsible or the extravagant salaries allowed many executive officers. He has been accustomed to raw large same; for expenses on his own uniterised vouchers."

The same authority reported of Mr. Alex- auder that he participated in Mr. Hyde's syndicate transactions, and accepted his share of the profit, that he executed leases which proved to be detrimental to the society’s in- terests; and that he failed to observe the 1 Obligations imposed on him.

It was stated in the two reports that Mrs. Jyde, the widow of the founder of theranit- Ve and the mother of the young gentleman ho helped himself so liberally to the funds of the company, received a pension of 65,000 per annum from the company though her husband had made an immense fortune by the dubious methods in which his son has followed him; that Mr. Alexander received a salary of 20,000; and that his wife, if she survived him, with farther guaranteed an annuity of 3,600; that three vice-preridents of the company received £190,000 per annum between them; and that the salaries of the cheif officials Had been increased 61 per cent in four years. It was asserted that sums of from £4,000 to 7,400,000 belonging to the Equitable were permitted to remain on deposit for a rate of interest much below that prevailing in the open market, in banks and companies in which The officials and directors of the Equitable were personally interested, and that the great fi- Nancial girl of Kuhn, Loeb and Co., whioh had A member on the board of the Equitable, had sold to it £10,000,000 of bonds in a period of Five years.
STATE INTERVENTION.

In view of these disclosures the State authorities at last took action, and suits have Been filled against forty-nine directors, calling upon them to account for their conduct and to make restitution for moneys illegally recieved And for gains wrongfully acquired.

Included among the defendents are the lead Ing men in the American business world, names -not to mention Mr. Hyde and Mr. Alex- ander— such as that of Senator Chauncey Depew, A. J. Cassatt, A. G. Vanderbilt, J. J. ator. August Belmont, W. C. Van Horne, and 1 E. H. Harriman, many of whom are multi- millionaires.

Deliberate frond is not imputed to the direc Tors in the State snit against them.. But they re charged with laxity and indifference of the rarest nature. The facts that the books of the company have been doctored and that two Notes by which £e00,0o0 and £300.000 were transferred were signed by a negro messenger In a receipt of a salary of £9 8s per week, is typical of the proceedings of the board.
FREE COOKING OF ACCOUNTS.

The New York Life, of which Mr. Perkins, A member of the famous Pierpont Morgan Firm, is a vice-president, is shown to have taken up £500,000 of bonds of the International. Mercantile Marine Company, which at the, date of issue the "Daily Mail" rightly describ- ed as mere “paper," and which are certainly scarifies that should never hare been touched By a first-rate insurance concern The Morgan firm issued those bonds end traded them off Insurance society.
To make its accounts look better, and con- ceal purchase of these bonds, the company

sold 160.000 of them back to Messre. Mor- Gan on December 81, 1903, so that they sbould in not appear in its inventory of investments of January 1, 1904, and on January 9 repurchas- ed them. The admission has been made that Its accounts on other heads were cooked. Thus A loss of £350,000 was manipulated and con- cealed. A farther example of the use kind Of transaction as that which took place with regard to the Shipping Trust bonds Was the purchase from an allied trust of £800,000 of Atlantic Coast line bonds, which were sold at A loss of £65,000 to clear the company’s books for the inspection of the State insurance authorities.

In the case of the New York Mutnal, the fact has been established that the officials of the company in some cases made profits by underwriting issues of bonds and then dispos- ing of a part of those issues to the company which they were managing, taking a toll of at from t to 4 per cent on such sales. It is not at alleged that the securities are not good or be intrinsically valuable, but that the officials be tinned against the true code of business moral- Sinned and against the law by making illicit profits.

div.head: CURIOS AND THEIR COLLECTORS.
div.p: The greatest crime of the Emperor Nero, that man of many and great crimes, was, according to an unsympathetic friend of a collector of curious, that committed when he bought the cloak which had belonged to Cato - for a sum representing £700 of our present currency, and thereby became the father of that multitude of men and women (but chiefly men) who collect curius of any shape or form. Of such men there most at the present moment Be a great army, and a list of the things they collect, together with an account of the manner in which they conduct their purchase, would make a most thrilling document The state- ment would receive additional piquancy if to it were added the comments of the said un- sympathetic friend, especially if that friend is of the collector’s household, and concerned with the housing and preservation of some of the more bulky and sensational objects. More money is said to ba spent—and, if we are to believe the anti-currie oollector, more conning di-played, more envy, hatred, - and malice exhibited—on the purchase and sale of curious of all sorts than on any other form of business transaction, and more for genes are successfully launched in this con- nexion than are dreamt of in the collectors philosophy. As for the perjuries and lies whioh are the direct result of the collector’s mania, these (we are still quoting the anti collector) are as the sand on tbs seashore for numbers and as ink for depth of dye In connexion with personal curios the Black Arts are supposed to be more frequently and Successfully practiced than with any other objeot that excites the cure-hunter’s passi n. This seems hardly surprising, seeing what excellent prices are paid for some of these things. Thus, one of Ronssean's old coats was recently sold in Paris for £30. and his brass watch for £50 while a French medical man , bought Voltaire's walking-stick for £30. The wig of Kant, the philosopher, fetched only £8; which seems a mean price when one recalls the fact that a hat of Starne sold for £1,200 at a London auction, for surely a wig, being a nearer neighbour to a great man's brain than his hat, should be accounted a more valuable possession than a mere beaver .

But the fact that there is no balance in the valuation of curlos, and that the whole “busi- ness” is only acrtiy, haphazard pursuit, is said to be brought out by the fact (disseminated in France) that, whereas “an English lord paid 680 for one of Newton’s teeth, the whole of The skull of Descarates changed owners at Stockholm for the miserable pittance of £40! Truly, collectors of curios are a strange com- munity. Bet it most he said for them that, judging from appearances and hearsay, no savage on the war-path and no detective in pursuit of criminals can have a more exciting Career than is theirs as they hunt and scheme and intrigue in order to possess themselves of Some coveted treasure.
